dc:description: CLIC2 was first reported in relation to X-linked complex neurodevelopmental disorder in 2012 by Takano et al., PMID: 22814392. The three individuals (from two unrelated families) reported to date in the literature with variants in this gene had  phenotypes including intellectual disability, delayed psychomotor development, seizures, and adult onset cardiac issues such as congestive heart failure, valvular insufficiency, atrial fibrillation, and cardiomegaly. Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found no difference in molecular mechanism, inheritance pattern, or phenotypic variability. Therefore, for the purposes of this curation, all of the reported disease entities, including syndromic X-linked mental retardation-32 (OMIM # 300886) and X-linked intellectual disability-cardiomegaly-congestive heart failure syndrome (ORPHA:324410, MONDO:0010473) have been lumped into one disease entity: X-linked complex neurodevelopmental disorder. Although two unique variants (both missense) have been reported in humans, the first published variant (Takano et al., PMID: 22814392) has been ruled out from disease-causality based on the presence of this variant in adult males in the (non-neuro) gnomAD population database (v.2.1.1). Given the dearth of experimental evidence linking CLIC2 with disease, and the scarcity of plausible reports of disease-causing variants in humans, the ClinGen Intellectual Disability and Autism Working Group recommended awarding 0 points for the second published variant, a missense change with no supportive functional data (Vissers et al., PMID: 28333917). In summary, there is disputed evidence supporting  the relationship between CLIC2 and X-linked complex neurodevelopmental disorder. More evidence is needed to either support or refute the role CLIC2 plays in this disease. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Intellectual Disability and Autism Working Group on 2/16/2021 (SOP Version 8).
curationReasonDescription: Due to the scarcity of plausible reports of disease-causing variants, and the lack of compelling experimental evidence, the relationship between CLIC2 and X-linked complex neurodevelopmental disorder is disputed.

evidence.dc:description: Per Gene Curation SOP (v8): "For dominant or X-linked disorders, the estimated LOD score should be calculated using ONLY families with 4 or more segregations present." This family has < 4 segregations, thus not using.
evidence.rdfs:label: K8015

member.rdfs:label: II-1
member.detectionMethod: Family segregation data suggested an X-linked form of intellectual disability so NGS sequencing was carried out for 718 X chr genes.
member.previousTestingDescription: LICAM sequencing and Fragile X testing were both performed: both negative. Microarray identified a few <1 Mb CNVs in the brothers, but causality was ruled out by presence of the same CNVs in an unaffected sister.

evidence.dc:description: Per GCEP, since there are no other compelling case reports nor experimental evidence linking this gene to complex neurodevelopmental disorder, we are not awarding points to this case.
Not awarding points for this case because none of the associated phenotypes fall into the realm of complex neurodevelopmental disorder.

The frequency of this variant is too high to be consistent with disease-causality. It occurs in 4 hemizygous males and 5 het females: https://gnomad.broadinstitute.org/variant/rs398122917?dataset=gnomad_r2_1
Per GCEP, seeing expression of a ubiquitously expressed protein in the brain (as well as in all other tissues) is not compelling enough expression data to award points.

RT –PCR analysis of CLIC2 in various human fetal tissues was conducted using cDNA preparations available in an MTC panel (Clontech) and primers covering exons 3– 6. CLIC2 was expressed in all tissues including the fetal brain. It is highly expressed in the fetal lung
and spleen. The expression of ACT8 was used as a control.
evidence.rdfs:label: Tissue expression of CLIC2

evidence.dc:description: Using this as case-level experimental data to support genetic evidence score for NM_001289.6(CLIC2):c.303C>G (p.His101Gln). Thus I do not want to score addl points here.
Increased open probability of RyR1 and RyR2 channels when exposed to mutant CLIC2-H101Q, as compared to open probability of RyR1 and RyR2 when exposed to WT CLIC2.
evidence.rdfs:label: Effects of p.H101Q-CLIC2 protein on RyR channel activity
